If this seems like a reasonable idea, I'll also post it to internals to get wider feedback, but I'd like to know if pursuing this direction would make sense to the rustdoc team.
Problem being that it adds JS for something that doesn't need it originally. :-/
And quite a heavy-maintenance one at that considering any DOM change will have to be fixed in there as well
The "hide everything" button already requires JS, though. It's only the individual ones that didn't, and I'm not sure that they get used much without also using the hide everything button.
Also, the individual ones are buggy, since https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/91103 doesn't work without JS.
We also know that https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/76a3b609d0b93c5d8da5e4e3db37bd03e5cb1c30 doesn't work with all screen readers, though it works with most of them.
And laying out section headers and disclosure buttons can not only result in a cluttered interface, but one with tiny clickable items right next to each other.
Basically, there are a lot of accessibility downsides with the current approach.
But with yours as well: I can't simply collapse everything and go through them with your solution.
What do you mean? Clicking the "filter" button collapses everything.
and the <details> work without JS, just a bit annoying with corner cases but it works
And finally, it seems very counter-intuitive to me to have to use the search input to collapse items
and it would also force me to empty it or to enter the item's name for it to be uncollapsed again
... that last one is a pretty good counterargument.
(also, I don't like discord search at all ^^')
It was a reference to Discourse, not Discord. I don't like very much of Discord's behavior either.

ah I see. I still never used its search though

so much for me reading the discourse search docs

In general I love the idea of showing all the [-]/ [+] only when needed.

I'm not sure the search metaphor is the right one, though. It feels like it's a totally different interface that happens to use the search box.

What do you think of the approach prototyped in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/86154 / https://jacob.hoffman-andrews.com/rust/invisible-toggles/std/string/struct.String.html#implementations ?

Clicking the [-] global time to hide everything, so that Ctrl+F search doesn't puck up words in the description.
